{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2013}} {{Infobox boxer |name = Boyd Melson |image = Boyd Melson.jpg |image_size = |realname = |nickname = Rainmaker{{cite web|url=http://boxrec.com/list_bouts.php?human_id=546458&cat=boxer |title=Boyd Melson – Boxer |publisher=BoxRec |date= |accessdate=August 9, 2011}} |weight = [[Light middleweight]] |height = {{convert|5|ft|10|in|m}} |reach = |nationality = {{flagicon|USA}} United States |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1981|10|16|mf=yes}} |birth_place = [[White Plains, New York]]{{cite news|url=http://www.usma.edu/dcomm/pv/050128/melson.htm |title= 2003 grad Melson named Outstanding Jewish Athlete of the Year |publisher=Usma.edu |date=January 28, 2005 |accessdate=August 9, 2011}} |death_date = |death_place = |style = |total = |wins = 15 |losses = 1 |draws = 1 |no contests = |KO = 4 |medaltemplates = {{MedalCompetition|[[International Military Sports Council|World Military Boxing Championship]]}} {{MedalGold| 2004 [[Fort Huachuca, Arizona]]|69 kg}} {{MedalCompetition|All Army Boxing Championships}} {{MedalGold| 2004|}} {{MedalGold| 2005|}} {{MedalCompetition|Armed Forces Boxing Championships}} {{MedalGold| 2004|}} {{MedalGold| 2005|}} {{MedalCompetition|[[U.S. national amateur boxing championships|US Amateur Boxing Championships]]}} {{MedalBronze| 2005|}} |show-medals = }} '''Boyd "Rainmaker" Melson''' (born October 16, 1981) is an American [[light middleweight]] boxer.{{cite news|url=http://www.nation.sc/index.php?art=4822 |title=Vèmes Jeux de la Francophonie à Niamey, au Niger|work=Seychelles Nation |date=December 6, 2005 |accessdate=August 9, 2011}} As an amateur, Melson won the 48th [[International Military Sports Council|World Military Boxing Championship]] [[gold medal]] in the 69 kg. weight class, and was a four-time [[United States Army]] champion, a three-time NCBA [[All-American]] boxer, a four-time West Point Brigade Open Boxing Champion, and received the Colonel Marcus Award. He also won gold medals at the All Army Boxing Championships twice and at the Armed Forces Boxing Championships twice. He made it to the quarterfinals in the welterweight [[2005 World Amateur Boxing Championships]], and won a bronze medal at the 2005 [[U.S. national amateur boxing championships|US Amateur Boxing Championships]]. As a professional, through May 2015, Melson was 15–1–1, with 4 of his wins coming by [[knockout]].{{cite news|url=http://news.boxrec.com/news/2011/behind-results-we-25-july11 |title=Behind The Results |author=Eric Armit |work=BoxRec News|date=July 25, 2011 |accessdate=August 9, 2011}} He is {{convert|5|ft|10|in|m}} tall, and weighs {{Unit weight|lb|154|0}}.{{cite news|author=Steve Lipman |url=http://www.thejewishweek.com/news/new_york/jewish_boxer_hurts_help_heal |title=A Jewish Boxer Hurts To Help Heal |work=The Jewish Week |date=July 14, 2011 |accessdate=August 9, 2011}} Melson donates all of the money that he earns in his boxing matches to [[stem cell research]] and his efforts have been profiled on [[Emmy Award]] winning [[HBO]] series [[Real Sports]], [[ESPN.com]], [[Sports Illustrated]] and [[Yahoo]]. In 2013, he was inducted into the [[National Jewish Sports Hall of Fame]]. ==Early and academic life== Melson is Jewish, and was born in [[White Plains, New York]], to an Israeli Jewish mother (Annette Melson; also an Army veteran) and a Creole father.{{cite web|url=http://www.train2perfection.com/2012/11/boyd-melson-is-fighting-for-a-cure/ |title=Boyd Melson is Fighting for a Cure |publisher=Train 2 Perfection |date= |accessdate=November 9, 2013}}{{cite web|author=Steve Lipman |url=http://www.thejewishweek.com/boyd_melson |title=Boyd Melson |publisher=The Jewish Week |date=July 14, 2011 |accessdate=November 9, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2012-10-19/news/34562209_1_boyd-melson-devon-alexander-pablo-cesar-cano/2 |title=Daily News America |publisher=NY Daily News |date= |accessdate=November 9, 2013}}{{cite news|author=Andrew Sherwood |url=http://www.totallyjewish.com/football/features/?content_id=16337 |title=Fighting On Two Fronts; Boxer Boyd Melson is a man on a mission.|publisher=TotallyJewish.com |date= |accessdate=August 9, 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://news.boxrec.com/news/2011/snips-and-snipes-25-july-2011 |title=Snips and Snipes |work=BoxRec News |date=July 25, 2011 |author=Eric Armit |accessdate=August 9, 2011}} His maternal grandparents were [[Holocaust survivor]]s from Poland.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dAq4TGQsWwwC&pg=PA310 |title=Day by day in Jewish sports history |publisher=KTAV Publishing House, Inc. |year=2008 |author=Bob Wechsler|ISBN=0-88125-969-1 |accessdate=August 9, 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://boricuaboxing.com/in-his-pro-debut-captain-boyd-melson-will-donate-his-entire-purse-to-stem-cell-research/ |title=In his Pro Debut, Captain Boyd Melson Will Donate His Entire Purse to Stem Cell Research |publisher= Borica Boxing|date= October 29, 2010|accessdate=August 9, 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.jewishtimes.com/index.php/jewishtimes/news/4047.stm/speechless/rubashkin_loses_bid_for_new_trial/ |title=Salita Promoting his Title Fight|work=Baltimore Jewish Times |date=October 29, 2010 |accessdate=August 9, 2011}} He said:
"My grandfather, while being put onto a train en route to a [[death camp]], escaped by sliding down the receptor tank full of defecation. It deposited him down the track allowing the train to pass over him until he could run off escaping. That is what he did to fight for his life and allow his bloodline of Judaism to pass down to his children, and now his grandchildren in me.”{{cite web|url=http://www.jns.org/latest-articles/2013/3/15/identity-through-athletics-the-jewish-sports-hall-of-fames-2013-class |title=‘Identity through athletics’: The Jewish Sports Hall of Fame’s 2013 class |publisher=Jns.org |date=March 15, 2013 |accessdate=November 9, 2013}}
He boxes with a [[Star of David]] on his trunks.{{cite news|url=http://www.trufanboxing.com/TaleOf%20The.htm |title=Tale Of The Tape; The Fighting Promotor Scores a KO |publisher=Trufanboxing.com |date=July 20, 2011 |accessdate=August 9, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.boydmelson.com/about.html |title=The Rainmaker-Boyd Melson; Behind the Gloves |publisher=Boydmelson.com |date= |accessdate=August 9, 2011}} Melson grew up primarily in [[Brooklyn, New York]]. Melson graduated from [[West Point]] in 2003 with a psychology degree, and a minor in [[nuclear engineering]].{{cite news|url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/boxing/2006-03-09-us-quarterfinals_x.htm |title=Melson wins U.S. boxing quarterfinals |work=USA Today |date=March 9, 2006 |accessdate=August 9, 2011}} He also graduated as a [[lieutenant]], and was promoted to [[Captain (United States)|captain]] three years later.{{cite news|url=http://www.usma.edu/dcomm/pv/041105/boyd.htm |title=2003 grad Boyd Melson wins CISM world |publisher=Usma.edu |date=November 5, 2004 |author=Tanja Linton |accessdate=August 9, 2011}} He earned an [[MBA]] in business administration at [[Touro College]].{{cite news|url=http://njjewishnews.com/kaplanskorner/2011/02/10/guest-column-alan-freedman-on-boyd-the-rainmaker-nelson/ |title=Guest column: Alan Freedman on Boyd ‘The Rainmaker’ Melson |work=New Jersey Jewish News |author=Alan Freedman |date=February 10, 2011 |accessdate=August 9, 2011}} ==Army champion and world military champion== Melson started boxing in [[National Collegiate Boxing Association]] (NCBA) competition while he was a [[cadet]] at West Point.{{cite web|url=http://www.jewishsports.org/jewishsports/detail.asp?sp=106 |title=Boyd Melson |publisher=The National Jewish Sports Hall of Fame and Museum |date=April 3, 2005 |accessdate=August 9, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110909082650/http://www.jewishsports.org:80/jewishsports/detail.asp?sp=106 |archivedate=September 9, 2011 |df=mdy }} He was picked for the [[US Army World Class Athlete Program]], and sent to [[Fort Carson]], [[Colorado]]. Melson was a four-time [[United States Army]] champion.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=B-5RAAAAIBAJ&sjid=iXQDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6952,758014&dq=boyd-melson&hl=en |title=Thurman Wins Again; Will Face Favorite Today |work=St. Petersburg Times |date=August 22, 2007 |author=John C. Cotey |accessdate=August 9, 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.eastsideboxing.com/news.php?p=28545&more=1 |title=Wladimir could fight Chisora-Fury winner; Wach-McBride on 7/29; Brighton Shore Fights |publisher=Eastsideboxing.com |date=July 5, 2011 |accessdate=August 9, 2011}} He was also a three-time NCBA [[All-American]] boxer, a four-time West Point Brigade Open Boxing Champion, and received the Colonel Marcus Award, which is given to the best West Point boxer at graduation. He was trained by former [[lightweight]] world champion [[Joey Gamache]]. In 2004, he won the 48th [[International Military Sports Council|World Military Boxing Championship]] [[gold medal]] in the 69 kg. weight class by defeating [[Elshod Rasulov]] of [[Uzbekistan]] at [[Fort Huachuca]], [[Arizona]] (as [[Ait Hammi Miloud]] of Morocco shared the bronze medal with Vyacheslav Kusov of Ukraine).{{cite web|url=http://armedforcessports.defense.gov/box04.html |title=2004 CISM Military Boxing Championships |publisher=Armedforcessports.defense.gov |date=November 1, 2004 |accessdate=August 9, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cism-milsport.org/eng/003_SPORTS/003_boxing/results.asp |title=48th World Military Boxing Championship, Fort Huachuca, Arizona, USA, 22–31 October 2004|publisher=CISM – Conseil International du Sport Militaire (International Military Sports Council)|date= |accessdate=August 9, 2011}} That year he also won gold medals at the All Army Boxing Championships and the Armed Forces Boxing Championships. Melson made it to the quarterfinals in the welterweight [[2005 World Amateur Boxing Championships]], losing to future pro star [[Erislandy Lara]] of Cuba, the eventual gold medal winner.{{cite web|url=http://www.amateur-boxing.strefa.pl/Championships/WorldChamps2005.html |title=World Championships; Mianyang, China; November 13–20, 2005 |publisher=Amateur-boxing.strefa.pl |date= |accessdate=August 9, 2011}} That year he also won gold medals at the All Army Boxing Championships and the Armed Forces Boxing Championships, and a bronze medal at the 2005 [[U.S. national amateur boxing championships|US Amateur Boxing Championships]]. He was an alternate on the 2008 U.S. Olympic Boxing Team, but withdrew with an injury.{{cite news|url=http://www.boxingnews24.com/2011/07/boxers-from-army%E2%80%99s-world-class-athlete-program-to-support-melson/ |title=Boxers from Army’s World Class Athlete Program to Support Melson! |publisher=Boxingnews24.com |date=July 17, 2011 |accessdate=August 9, 2011}} ==Professional career== Melson became a professional in 2010 to raise research funds to honor a woman who had been his girlfriend.{{cite web|url=http://www.doghouseboxing.com/Chee/Chee1109eee05.htm |title=USA Boxing news: The Countdown to the Opening Bell Begins |publisher=Doghouseboxing.com |date=November 9, 2005 |accessdate=October 8, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.eastsideboxing.com/news.php?p=12054&more=1 |title=The Nation’s Top Boxers to Face Off at the U.S. Olympic Team Trials – Boxing, August 20–26 |publisher=Eastsideboxing.com |date=August 13, 2007 |accessdate=October 8, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/boxing/news/story?id=2360461 |title=Melson wins at 152 lbs.; defending champs advance |publisher=ESPN |date=March 8, 2006 |accessdate=October 8, 2011}} She had been in a wheelchair for 17 years, since the age of 10, following a diving accident. They had met during his senior year at West Point, when she was already using a wheelchair due to a diving accident. Melson worked tirelessly to educate himself on spinal cord injuries and stem cell research. He traveled abroad with girlfriend Christan Zaccagnino so she could undergo experimental procedures that are not currently offered in the United States. While there, they were exposed to the vast expansion of work being done in this field that does not involve the use of embryonic stem cells.Boxing 101, [http://www.worldboxing101.com/2012/12/11/boxer-boyd-melson-is-on-a-soldiers-fight-to-walk/ "Boxer Boyd Melson Is On A Soldier's Fight To Walk"], December 11, 2012 Melson donates all of the money he earns in his boxing matches to [[stem cell research]]. He gives it to Justadollarplease.org, a [[non-profit organization]] that raises money for the first U.S. [[spinal cord injury]] trial in using [[umbilical cord]] [[stem cells]]. Along with Justadollarplease.org, Melson created Team Fight to Walk, to increase awareness in boxing of the importance of stem cell research for spinal cord injuries. Team Fight to Walk is composed of Melson, former [[Rutgers University]] football player [[Eric LeGrand]], former two-time [[IBF]] [[Cruiserweight (boxing)|cruiserweight]] champion [[Steve Cunningham]], US Olympians [[Shawn Estrada]] and [[Demetrius Andrade]] and contender [[Deandre Latimore]] amongst other boxers. Through April 2014, Melson was 14–1–1, with 4 of his wins by way of knockout and the sole defeat coming via controversial decision in what was considered one of the best local fights on the New York scene in recent memory. [[Welterweight]] [[Dmitry Salita]] said of him following a May 2011 bout: "I have seen tremendous improvement in Boyd in the last two fights. He is a very talented fighter and sets an example inside and outside the ring." Since 2012, Melson has been training with head coach Simon Bakinde {{cite web|url=http://www.worldboxingnews.net/news/press-releases/2013/04/24/perez-steps-in-to-oppose-melson-on-saturday-night.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-02-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140227183647/http://www.worldboxingnews.net/news/press-releases/2013/04/24/perez-steps-in-to-oppose-melson-on-saturday-night.html |archivedate=February 27, 2014 |df=mdy }} ==Professional boxing record== {{S-start}} | style="text-align:center;" colspan="8"|'''15 Wins''' (4 Knockouts 11 decisions), ''' 1 Loss''', '''1 Draw''' |- style="text-align:center; background:#e3e3e3;" | style="border-style:none none solid solid; "|'''Res.''' | style="border-style:none none solid solid; "|'''Record''' | style="border-style:none none solid solid; "|'''Opponent''' | style="border-style:none none solid solid; "|'''Type''' | style="border-style:none none solid solid; "|'''Rd., Time''' | style="border-style:none none solid solid; "|'''Date''' | style="border-style:none none solid solid; "|'''Location''' | style="border-style:none none solid solid; "|'''Notes''' |- align=center |{{N/A}} |{{N/A}} ||align=left|{{flagicon|US}} Russ Niggemyer |{{large|[[Sergio Martinez vs. Darren Barker|-]]}} |{{small|? (6)}} |{{small|2011-10-01}} |align=left|{{small|{{flagicon|USA}} [[Boardwalk Hall]], [[Atlantic City, New Jersey|Atlantic City]], [[New Jersey]]}} |align=left| |- align=center {{S-end}} ==Honors== He was honored as the 2005 [[Marty Glickman]] Outstanding Jewish Scholastic (college) Athlete of the Year by the [[National Jewish Sports Hall of Fame]]. In 2013, he was inducted into the National Jewish Sports Hall of Fame. He said, as to his induction: "I am pleased to show that [Jews] can excel in all areas of human endeavor, and that is what is of great importance to me in being honored." ==Personal life== Outside of boxing, he works for [[Johnson & Johnson]] in the Ethicon Division. He also serves as an [[Army Reserves]] Captain of the 1179th Transportation Brigade at [[Fort Hamilton]], in [[Brooklyn]].
